column7: This Monday @LIZJNYshow look at strangles and iron condors in SPY and talk about IVR. They adjust the $SNOW position and place new earnings trades in retail and oil - https://t.co/aKnRVVwMbO https://t.co/Sa6ofkNuXs

The market presents a unique opportunity where call skew is prevalent in a lot of popular stocks. @tastytraderMike & @TraderNickyBAT  breaks down what that means for options strategies today - https://t.co/LCtBuPGHE9 https://t.co/GFIJlzYWs6

Now you can access 2YR, 10YR, and 30YR interest rates in small, simple futures! @frank_kaberna and @traderpetem dive into the specs and opportunities around these new products - https://t.co/rXUkWlcpFY https://t.co/KmCqfuCcBB

When you begin to widen out your Iron Condors, they start to act more like an undefined-risk position than a defined-risk position. Tune in as @jschultzf3 explains - https://t.co/Y5RLRVdQKd https://t.co/PepIl5MlU8

Now that Tom's two students have a few trades under their belt, they take a step back and talk through building habits of market awareness and how it can be utilized to approach options trades or portfolio management on a regular basis - https://t.co/Z77CCgJCSx https://t.co/HaARfj9GEW

It can be tempting to try to use the standard deviation of returns, the “historical volatility,” in an underlying to think about future price movements. Tom & @Tony_BATtista go over some pitfalls with this approach and reiterate the advantages of IV - https://t.co/ZRcSfIx8OD https://t.co/UXSXdkUQ1g

Exiting trades is just as important as trade entry. There are a few factors options traders should consider when looking to exit a position. Tune in as Tom & @Tony_BATtista explore them - https://t.co/I1g3a8NFUb https://t.co/R3jBTQmbiA

A call diagonal spread is a bullish trade where we purchase an ITM long call with more time than the OTM short call we sell against it to reduce cost basis. @tastytraderMike & @TraderNickyBAT show you how they set these trades up & look at a few tactics - https://t.co/8HgD52JP4h https://t.co/nZOlVdjhj6

Oftentimes, the higher-order Greeks become very theoretical and lose their applicability to real-time trading. But here in episode #6 of the Greeks Crash Course, we learn about Charm, which might be the most important higher-order Greek, next to Gamma. https://t.co/k6wDgMvoa3

Here in episode #7, we are introduced to Color, which is a second-order derivative of the Black-Scholes Model that measures how Gamma changes over time. So in essence, Color shows us the mathematical support for Gamma Risk’s existence. https://t.co/2LFbUlrHca

Streaks of large down days are quite uncommon, with only 31 streaks of 3 or more 1% down moves in the $SPX since 1993, looking at ~8000 trading days of data. 
https://t.co/caoR4lxddg

Single down days, or short term selloffs, provide excellent opportunities to sell strangles due to the higher P/L and credit you receive. Generally, selling strangles after down days saw an increase in average P/Ls because rapid IV increases. https://t.co/68xDlMwhpa

We looked at what happens after streaks of up or down days. Over the last 30 years, you could expect a streak of at least three 1% days to the same direction to happen less than 1% of the time, half being up-day streaks and half being down-day streaks. 
https://t.co/qjVKh9B7WW
